WRITING.TITLE: TIL Extracted documents from the MA Archives question whether Israel Bissell rode all the way to Philadelphia. The documents reportedly support he did ride with news of the attack on Lexington but only to CT, billing for six days of expenses while in CT, rather than a full trip to Philadelphia.

TIL "Sokushinbutsu" is the practice of Buddhist monks observing austerity to the point of death and mummification. The process of self-mummification was mainly practiced in Yamagata in Northern Japan between the 11th and 19th century.

TIL In September 2010 cosplay participants dressed as Pedobear were accused of being pedophiles after the San Luis Obispo County Sheriff's Department issued a warning that Pedobear was a sign of the presence of pedophiles and suggested that Pedobear was a kind of mascot among pedophiles.

TIL In May 1997, Mattel introduced Share a Smile Becky, a doll in a pink wheelchair. A 17-year-old high school student with cerebral palsy pointed out the doll wouldnt fit in the elevator of Barbie's Dream House. Mattel announced it would redesign the house in the future to accommodate the doll.

TIL Professor Patrick Michaud performed an experiment in 1994 showing strawberry Pop-Tarts could produce foot high flames when left in a toaster too long, triggering lawsuits. Pop-Tarts now carry a warning: "Due to possible risk of fire, never leave your toasting appliance or microwave unattended."
TIL William Lee was the only one of George Washington's 124 slaves freed outright in Washington's will citing "his faithful services during the Revolutionary War".

TIL When prohibition was repealed in 1933, Yuengling beer Company sent a truckload of "Winner Beer" to President Franklin D. Roosevelt in appreciation, which arrived the day the amendment was repealed particularly notable since Yuengling beer takes almost three weeks to brew and age.

TIL The US Congress voted to pay George Washington $25,000 a year. He declined since he valued his image as a selfless public servant but ultimately accepted to avoid a precedent where the presidency would be perceived as limited only to wealthy individuals who could serve without pay.

TIL In ancient Athens, a person who committed suicide without the approval of the state was denied the honors of a normal burial. The person would be buried alone, on the outskirts of the city, without a headstone. However it was deemed to be an acceptable method to deal with military defeat.

TIL The first non-electric, gas lit, traffic lights were installed in London in December 1868 but exploded in January 1869 due to a gas leak which injured (or killed) the policeman operating the light. The concept was abandoned until a safer alternative came along.

TIL In George Washingtons farewell address, he warned against foreign influence in domestic affairs, bitter partisanship in domestic politics, permanent alliances with any portion of the foreign world, and called for men to move beyond partisanship and serve the common good.

TIL Tater Tots were created in 1953 when Ore-Ida founders F. Nephi Grigg and Golden Grigg were trying to figure out what to do with leftover slivers of cut-up potatoes. The product was first offered in stores in 1956.

TIL The Dunkin' Donuts chain in Thailand used an advertisement in 2013 that contained a photograph of a woman in black face-paint to promote its new chocolate flavored donuts. The company was criticized, with the Human Rights Watch calling the advertisement bizarre and racist.

TIL Samuel Gray, the first man fired upon in the Boston Massacre, was mortally shot by Private Matthew Killroy after calling out God damn you, dont fire! when the violence erupted. The most common fact about Gray is that he worked as rope maker and was a notorious street agitator.

TIL In-N-Out Burger prints discreet references to Bible verses on their paper containers. These consist of the book, chapter, and number of the verse, not the text of the passage, in small print on an inconspicuous area of the item. The practice began in the 1980s.

TIL Due to a 1999 incident of an employee stealing firearms in transit to licensed firearm dealers UPS issued a policy that all handguns must be shipped overnight. "We're trying to protect ourselves from employees stealing and criminals stealing." UPS spokesman Bob Godlewski said.

WRITING.TEXT: EDIT: Many many awesome songs listed here. Thanks for the contributions and reminding me of many I've long forgotten but now gladly remember!
